prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Obtain a Band 3 map the Arches W1 region
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Target the CS cloud locate along the Western rim of the thermal Arched filaments

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The typical line widths of CMZ clouds are between 5 to 10 km/s wide. However, on arc second scales, the lines are often much narrower with widths of order 1 o 3 km/s. Thus we need a spectral resolution between 1 - 2 km/s for this project
Also, to diagnose a core as being externally heated vs. internally heated, we need to identify the large number of hot core gas tracers such as those seen in nearby cores such as Orion. Species such as methanol would be seen in hot cores. Thus, we need 1 - 2 km/s spectral resolution through our ~8 GHz observing band. The bandwidth is also needed for continuum sensitivity. The spectral resolution will enable us to separate the forest of expected line in a hot core form the dust continuum.

The 2 angular resolution reaches a size scale of about 0.1 pc, the typical size scale of core giving birth to moderate mass (> a few Solar masses) and high mass stars. If compact cores with fluxes above 1 mJy are detected, then they must be high density cores and their mid-IR flux most likely originates from an embedded protostar.

The CMZ molecular lines are bright with temperatures of of order 2 to 5 K in clouds, and 3 to 10 K in hot cores. We are searching for dust continuum from hot cores associated with the birth of massive stars. The dust continuum from such objects at 3 mm can range from several Jy for the most massive ones to about less than 1 mJy for low mass one. For example, the 150 Solar mass core embedded in the dark cloud G0.253+0.002 (the Brick) has a flux of about 3 Jy in a 2 ALMA beam.
The 2 angular resolution reaches a size scale of about 0.1 pc, the typical size scale of core giving birth to moderate mass (> a few Solar masses) and high mass stars. If compact cores with fluxes above 1 mJy are detected, then they must be high density cores and their mid-IR flux most likely originates from an embedded protostar.
The dust continuum flux at 3 mm expected from a 10 Solar mass core can be estimated from S(3mm) = M(Mo) B(T) kappa(3mm) / R(gas-dust) D^2 where B(T) is the Planck function, kappa(3mm) is the dust emissivity at 3 mm, and R(gas-dust) = 100 is the gas-to-dust ratio, and D is the distance.
Extrapolating the Ossenkopf & Henning (1994, A&A, 291, 943) opacities to 3 mm using frequency dependence of the emissivity (beta) scaling as 3.5, implies that kappa(3mm) = 0.007 - 0.02 cm^2 / gram of dust. We use a distance D = 8 to 8.5 kpc for the CMZ.
Assuming a dust temperature of 20 K, the expected 3 mm flux density from a 10 Solar mass core within the beam is S(3mm) = 100 to 300 micro-Jy. However, an internally heated core may higher grain temperatures.

To diagnose a core as being externally heated vs. internally heated, we need to identify the large number of hot core gas tracers such as those seen in nearby cores such as Orion. Species such as methanol would be seen in hot cores. Thus, we need 1 - 2 km/s spectral resolution through our ~8 GHz observing band. The bandwidth is also needed for continuum sensitivity. The spectral resolution will enable us to separate the forest of expected line in a hot core form the dust continuum. We require both large bandwidth, and high spectral resoltuion.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Copy of Obtain a Band 3 map the Arches E1 region
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Target the CS cloud locate along the North-eastern rim of the thermal Arched filaments

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Copy of Obtain a Band 3 map the Sickle region
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Target the Sickle cloud next to the Quintuplet cluster

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The Central Molecular Zone (CMZ) contains the largest concentration of dense molecular gas in the Galaxy. Herschel and Spitzer found dozens of compact 24 and 70 micron sources with luminosities ranging from 1,000 to 10,000 Solar luminosities along the rim of the 30 pc diameter bubble located between longitudes of 0 and 0.2 degrees. The bubble contain two of the most massive young star clusters in the Milky Way with a Lyman continuum luminosity of nearly 10^52 ionizing photons / sec. We propose to use ALMAs high angular resolutions and sensitivity to determine if the 70 micron sources contain massive protostars, or are externally heated, non-star forming clouds reprocessing the intense radiation field of the massive stars and star clusters located 5 to 15 pc from the mid-IR sources. We propose a Band 3 survey of the continuum and serval gas tracers to search for of compact gas and dust cores that may contain protostars. This project has major implications for determinations of star formation rates in the CMZ and in distant galaxies where where resolution is poor.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Astrophysical and Planetary Sciences, Colorado at Boulder, Univ of

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Astrophysics Research Institute, Liverpool John Moores University
Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory, Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics
